## Introduction

Welcome to the **GoldinGroundOz** package!
This vignette walks through how the package was built and what it aims to demonstrate.

Before we begin, an important reminder:

ğŸ’¬ All data in this package are simulated.
They were generated to **resemble the general patterns** of real-world Australian housing and income trends â€”
but they are **not actual figures**, and no real economic inference should be drawn from them.

## The Idea

The story behind the name Gold in the Ground is simple â€”
Australiaâ€™s housing market has long been a fascinating subject,
with property prices often growing faster than household income.

## Dataset and Variable

To explore this idea visually, we created two small datasets:

-  housepr_income: showing detached house prices and household disposable income
over 1990â€“2023, both simulated to move in a realistic long-term pattern.

```{r}
knitr::kable(
  data.frame(
    Variable = c("year", "income", "house_price"),
    Description = c(
      "Calendar year (1990â€“2023). Each record represents a yearly observation.",
      "Simulated household disposable income index. It increases gradually, reflecting moderate real income growth.",
      "Simulated detached house price index. It rises faster after the 2000s to mimic Australia's property boom."
    )
  ),
  caption = "Variables in the `housepr_income` dataset"
)

```


-  capital_gain: representing average capital gain rate changes between 1986â€“2020,
with a policy-phase split (â€œBeforeâ€ vs. â€œAfterâ€ the 50% capital gains discount).

```{r}
knitr::kable(
  data.frame(
    Variable = c("year", "phase", "value"),
    Description = c(
      'Financial year period formatted as "YYYY-YY" (e.g., "1999-00").',
      'Policy phase: either "Before 50% capital gains discount" or "After 50% capital gains discount".',
      "Simulated average capital gain rate (in basis points). Values rise gradually after the policy change."
    )
  ),
  caption = "Variables in the `capital_gain` dataset"
)

```


Again, both are **artificial**, designed only to mimic the shape of real-world trends.

## Loading the Data

```{r setup}
library(GoldinGroundOz)
data("housepr_income")
data("capital_gain")

head(housepr_income)
head(capital_gain)

```

## Visualizing

```{r}
#| echo: false
plot(
housepr_income$year, housepr_income$house_price,
type = "l", col = "gold", lwd = 2,
ylab = "Index (1989â€“90 = 100)", xlab = "Year",
main = "Simulated Detached House Prices vs Household Disposable Income"
)
lines(housepr_income$year, housepr_income$income, col = "#FF8C69", lwd = 2)
legend("topleft",
legend = c("House Prices", "Disposable Income"),
col = c("gold", "#FF8C69"), lwd = 2, bty = "n")

```

What we see is purely a stylized representation â€”
income grows steadily, while house prices accelerate more strongly after the 2000s.
This matches the broad shape of historical data, without using any real numbers.
